awd_titl_txt: Multi-Functional Optical Meta-Systems Enabled by Deep-Learning-Aided Inverse Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Artificial intelligence especially deep learning has enabled many breakthroughs in both academia and industry. This project aims to create a generative and versatile design approach based on novel deep learning techniques to realize integrated, multi-functional photonic systems, and provide proof-of-principle demonstrations in experiments. Compared with traditional approaches using extensive numerical simulations or inverse design algorithms, deep learning can uncover the highly complicated relationship between a photonic structure and its properties from the dataset, and hence substantially accelerate the design of novel photonic devices that simultaneously encode distinct functionalities in response to the designated wavelength, polarization, angle of incidence and other parameters. Such multi-functional photonic systems have important applications in many areas, including optical imaging, holographic display, biomedical sensing, and consumer photonics with high efficiency and fidelity, to benefit the public and the nation. The integrated education plan will considerably enhance outreach activities and educate students in grades 7-12, empowered by the successful experience and partnership previously established by the PIs. Graduate and undergraduate students participating in the project will learn the latest developments in the multidisciplinary fields of photonics, deep learning and advanced manufacturing, and gain real-world knowledge by engaging industrial collaborators in tandem with Northeastern University's renowned cooperative education program.
Technical Description: Metasurfaces, which are two-dimensional metamaterials consisting of a planar array of subwavelength designer structures, have created a new paradigm to tailor optical properties in a prescribed manner, promising superior integrability, flexibility, performance and reliability to advance photonics technologies. However, so far almost all metasurface designs rely on time-consuming numerical simulations or stochastic searching approaches that are limited in a small parameter space. To fully exploit the versatility of metasurfaces, it is highly desired to establish a general, functionality-driven methodology to efficiently design metasurfaces that encompass distinctly different optical properties and performances within a single system. The objective of the project is to create and demonstrate a high-efficiency, two-level design approach enabled by deep learning, in order to realize integrated, multi-functional meta-systems. Proper deep learning methods, such as Conditional Variational Auto-Encoder and Deep Bidirectional-Convolutional Network, will be investigated, innovatively reformulated and tailored to apply at the single-element level and the large-scale system level in combination with topology optimization and genetic algorithm. Such a generative design approach can directly and automatically identify the optimal structures and configurations out of the full parameter space. The designed multi-functional optical meta-systems will be fabricated and characterized to experimentally confirm their performances. The success of the project will produce transformative photonic architectures to manipulate light on demand.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This project has developed a new strategy based on deep learning to design multifunctional optical metasurfaces, which are two-dimensional metamaterials composed of engineered metallic or dielectric nanostructures. The design framework incorporate a two-level approach, utilizing deep learning at both the single-element (or meta-atom) level and the large-scale system level. Traditional approaches, which rely on physical intuition or numerical simulations, inherently limit the design speed, function capacity, and device performance. The deep-learning-based design framework can overcome these limitations by revealing the intricate relationships between metasurface structures and their optical properties through extensive data analysis. Using this framework, the team has designed and characterized novel optical metasurfaces capable of simultaneously encoding multiple functionalities in response to wavelength, polarization, and angle of incidence. The project has resulted in 20 publications in scientific journals, including Science, Nature Photonics, Advanced Materials, and Advanced Optical Materials, along with over 20 invited talks/seminars and 6 oral/poster presentations. Some highlights of the project include: (1) the development of a deep generative model with an encoder-decoder structure, which can address the one-to-many mapping issue in inverse design and retrieve diverse meta-atom geometries based on the required spectra; (2) the creation of an end-to-end framework that fully explores metasurface design space, enabling metasurface focusing lenses and holograms with up to eight controllable responses across different combinations of working wavelengths and linear polarization states; (3) breaking the fundamental limit of polarization multiplexing capacity of metasurfaces that roots from the dimension constraints of the Jones matrix, by introducing the engineered noise to the precise solution of Jones matrix elements; and (4) the demonstration of structured light generation using angle-multiplexed metasurfaces.

Broader impacts: The demonstrated multifunctional devices and systems, including metasurface lenses and holograms, offer advantages of high efficiency, ultra-thin profiles, and ease of fabrication. They have important applications in optical imaging, holographic displays, virtual and augmented reality, with significant potential to benefit the public. Although the project focused on optical metasurfaces designed by deep learning, the design approach can be extended to other platforms working at different electromagnetic spectra, including but not limited to integrated silicon photonic devices and microwave/radio antennas and receivers. This highly interdisciplinary project provides comprehensive training for students. Six Ph.D. students supervised by PI Liu and co-PI Fu were supported by the project and directly contributed to the proposed research. They have gained fundamental knowledge and developed diverse skills in areas of nanophotonics, optical metamaterials, artificial intelligence, nanofabrication, and device characterization. In addition, one Ph.D. student in PI Liu's group completed an internship at CoCoPIE with support from the NSF INTERN supplementary grant, which provided him with invaluable experience in a startup environment. After graduation, these students furthered their careers in either industry (such as Senior Research Scientist at Meta Generative AI, Research Scientist at Salesforce AI Research, and Senior Quality Engineer at MathWorks) or academia (including tenure-track Assistant Professor at Rochester Institute of Technology, postdoctoral research fellow at McGill University, and postdoctoral research fellow at Polytechnique Montreal). PI Liu has incorporated fundamental knowledge and recent breakthroughs in metamaterials and metasurfaces into his course EECE 5647 "Nanophotonics" to educate students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels, aiming to enhance their awareness and interest in the forefront of optics and photonics.
